tableOfContents.title: SECTION I: Introduction to the Business Continuity Plan (BCP)
SECTION II: Quick Activation and Engagement Guide
This section is designed for use by the CPR, BFT members and their delegates, or other key stakeholders to determine if the severity of the incident warrants a Business Continuity Plan activation.
SECTION V: Recovery Strategies- Business Critical
Recovery strategies & workarounds (Only business critical tools)
Business Process Scope and Recovery Timeframes (RTO)
BUILDING/LOCATION UNAVAILABILITY:  Refer to this section in the event one or more of your production locations is not accessible for any reason.
EQUIPMENT UNAVAILABILITY:  Refer to this section in the event your equipment or hardware is not working, such as your computer, telephone, scanner, printer, etc.

Personnel Shortage
Refer to this section if you experience a personnel shortage or if additional requirements are needed for a pandemic.

Fill out the section below for all potential scenarios (4 examples below) for which your Business Process can be impacted. Separate into different sections for scenarios where remediation steps are not the same.

content.content: The objective of the Business Continuity Plan is to minimize impact to critical business processes by coordinating recovery efforts in the event of a disaster or business interruption. Types of disasters and interruptions include both short-term and long-term incidents including, but not limited to, natural disasters, power outages, application outages, terrorism, pandemic, cyberattacks, etc.

A business interruption is defined as any event (anticipated or unanticipated) that disrupts normal business operations. A disaster is defined as a sudden, unplanned catastrophic event compromising an organization’s ability to provide critical business processes or services for an unacceptable period of time.

The plan scope is limited to the business function identified on the cover page only. The plan scope does not include emergency management. The list of business processes covered in this plan can be found on the “Business Process Scope and Recovery Timeframes (RTO)” table.

The BCP applies when a business interruption/disaster directly or indirectly decreases the capacity of our critical business processes which impacts Cisco’s ability to deliver services to our customers. Depending on the impact of the incident, some parts of the plan may not apply.

The BCP is used by key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts of their specific function. The plan is a guide for key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts by facilitating communication, creating an action plan, executing workaround strategies, and returning to normal operations.
There are a few terms mentioned in the document that are worth highlighting and defined as follows:
BFT: Business Function Team (Primary Contacts to be Alerted)
DM:  On-call Duty Manager
RTO: Recovery Time Objective
CXC CPR: CXC Crisis Preparedness and Response Team

section_ii_quick_activation_and_engageme.title: SECTION II: Quick Activation and Engagement Guide

content.content: The following flowchart helps identify if activation of the Business Continuity Plan is required and how to engage the appropriate stakeholders to keep critical business processes operating. See next page for additional details.

Using judgement, key stakeholders should determine if the business interruption is severe enough where it will exceed business-defined recovery time objectives (RTO) to activate the Business Continuity Plan (see next page for in scope processes and the respective RTO).
Other criteria to consider when activating a BCP include:
On-Call CPR Team
CPR Team Incident Open and Epage (If NaaS E-Page or CLIP unavailable, go to step 2)
CXC CPR Team On-Call (VPN needed, if unavailable CPR contact information is listed with the BFT)
CIC Duty Manager
CIC On-Call
The BFT coordinates all continuity activities and controls the implementation of the plan.
Cisco e-page: cap-bft-epage
If ePage is down, use the following table to contact the bft.
Mailer members

content.name: Crisis Preparedness And Response
content.title: None
raw_data: All Cisco CX Centers Business Units
CPR engagement can be initiated by any business function in CX Centers

content.content: The On-call CPR Lead identifies whether a Business Continuity (BC) incident should be reported to the Business Function Team (BFT).
The CPR team determines the point person for handling a BC incident, unless this is delegated to an Event Manager (EM).
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.
CPR team will assess the impact and pages out the BFT (ce-bft-epage) to begin crisis communication. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:
Start or join a WebEx meeting (if available): https://cisco.webex.com/cisco
If Webex is not available, the following Everbridge Dial-In-Bridge can be activated:
Hosting a call:
To invite participants to your conference call, provide them with the Everbridge Dial-In Number and the Conference ID and passcode number:
Dial-In Number
Conference ID #: Passcode
If Everbridge Dial-In Bridge cannot be activated, CPR Lead uses mobile phone to organize BFT briefing with appropriate and available BFT Members

Form a BFT Command Center and Action Plan

Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via WebEx and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.
In case of a pandemic alert (WHO Phase 4+), the Cisco Global Pandemic Coordinator will convene BC teams for pandemic monitoring and response.

Execute the BFT Action Plan

Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
CPR Lead assumes responsibility.
Assign personnel as needed
Communicate with vendors as required
Act as a decision maker in the allocation of resources during the plan execution period
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Ensure all continuity tasks are appropriately executed
Implement the appropriate business continuity strategies

Return to Normal Operations

Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
Identify and coordinate requirements to transition back to normal operations
Ensure business function restoration is successful
Inform all required stakeholders of restoration process (business unit, vendors, suppliers, etc.)
Provide return to normal communication to required stakeholders as outlined below
The table below outlines business critical tools and indicates whether alternative solutions are available for each.

fill_out_the_section_below_for_all_poten.title: Fill out the section below for all potential scenarios (4 examples below) for which your Business Process can be impacted. Separate into different sections for scenarios where remediation steps are not the same.

content.content: Scenario Types:
Natural Disaster (Earthquake, Tornado, Flooding, anything applicable to your geographical location, etc.)
Technological (Network outage, DNS outage, communications outage, critical application outage etc.)
Human/Community Impact (Pandemic, War, etc.)
Cyber Attack (Critical application hacked for your business process and data stolen)
Summary of incident: Briefly describe the incident. Incidents can vary and range from personnel, technology, natural disasters, cyber-attacks, etc.

Remediation Steps: Describe each step in as much detail as would be necessary for someone unfamiliar with the system (but technically capable) to follow and complete the remediation. Contact the appropriate stakeholders (recovery teams) and provide crisis communications as necessary. Utilize workaround strategies until service/facility/technology/etc. resumes.

Technologies utilized for the remediation process: List applications, scripts, systems necessary to complete the remediation steps. Standard Cisco applications and several other critical tools such as CSOne and other apps with their respective recovery strategies listed above.

Personnel Skills Required: Describe the number of personnel and specific skills essential for the remediation steps above. Customer Service, Cisco Equipment Experience, diploma or technical background.

Post remediation monitoring: Describe any logs, dashboards, etc. that should be monitored post-remediation to ensure stability of the recovered system(s). Any offline or manual work should be reconciled as appropriate. Continue to monitor for any further potential issues that may arise.

Post resolution procedures: Describe additional tasks/procedures that should be completed post resolution such as bug reports, configuration changes, change request updates, other potential system failures, etc. Notes may need to be recorded into the appropriate platform. See resumption procedures for applications.
This is an offline directory for use to contact teams should the online directory not be available.

Emergency Customer Communication Templates

These templates have been provided for quick reference when it is necessary to alert customers to emergency situations that prevent or severely limit service delivery. The templates provided have been approved by Corporate Communications for use during emergent situations.

Instructions for use: The BFT should discuss if customer communications are necessary with current or expected circumstances, and nominate one individual to prepare and modify these templates for distribution to customers. Existing CMS tools may provide a method of managing these email communications.
Three templates are provided:
Temporary Impact to CMS Support
Temporary Impact to CMS Communications
Temporary Impact to CMS Response Times
Subject: Important Notice: Temporary Impact to CMS Support
Dear Customer,

CMS is experiencing an issue with our [internal tools/network access to your network/remote access to your network] and as a result, this may impact our ability to provide service for your account. Our teams are actively working to address the situation and will keep you updated on any significant changes.

We appreciate your understanding and patience during this period. If you have any urgent issues, please don't hesitate to contact your Services Manager, who will do their best to connect you with the support you need.
Thank you for your continued support and cooperation.
Best regards,
[Your Name]
Subject: Important Notice: Temporary Impact to CMS Communications
Dear Customer,

CMS is experiencing an issue with our [phone/email/ebonding] services and as a result, this may impact our ability to [respond to calls/respond to email requests/process ebonded requests]. Our teams are actively working to address the situation and will keep you updated on any significant changes.

We appreciate your understanding and patience during this period. If you have any urgent issues, please don't hesitate to contact your Services Manager, who will do their best to connect you with the support you need.
Thank you for your continued support and cooperation.
Best regards,
[Your Name]

temporary_impact_to_cms_response_times.title: Temporary Impact to CMS Response Times

content.content: Subject: Important Notice: Temporary Impact to CMS Response Times
Dear Customer,

CMS is experiencing a service impacting event and as a result, you may encounter delays in our usual response and service times. Our teams are actively working to address the situation and will keep you updated on any significant changes.

We appreciate your understanding and patience during this period. If you have any critical issues or outages, please don't hesitate to contact your Services Manager, who will do their best to connect you with the support you need.
Thank you for your continued support and cooperation.
Best regards,
[Your Name]

Personnel Shortage: Refer to this section if you experience a personnel shortage or if additional requirements are needed for a pandemic.

Recovery Scenarios and Processes: Fill out the section below for all potential scenarios (4 examples below) for which your Business Process can be impacted. Separate into different sections for scenarios where remediation steps are not the same.

content.content: 1. Scope
Scope

The plan scope is limited to the business function identified on the cover page only. The plan scope does not include emergency management. The list of business processes covered in this plan can be found on the “Business Process Scope and Recovery Timeframes (RTO)” table.
2. How to use the BCP
How to use the BCP

The BCP applies when a business interruption/disaster directly or indirectly decreases the capacity of our critical business processes which impacts Cisco’s ability to deliver services to our customers. Depending on the impact of the incident, some parts of the plan may not apply.

The BCP is used by key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts of their specific function. The plan is a guide for key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts by facilitating communication, creating an action plan, executing workaround strategies, and returning to normal operations.
3. Quick Activation and Engagement Guide
Quick Activation and Engagement Guide

Step 1: Category = Incident Awareness: In the event of an incident, the Duty Manager (DM) or designated leader should initiate contact with the Crisis Preparedness and Response (CPR) team by submitting a request as outlined on page 8. The CPR team can also be reached via email at ce-cpr-team@cisco.com or by phone using the contact information provided in the BFT list.

Step 2: Category = Life Safety: Ensure life safety of employees. Utilize the Global Emergency Response Plan for procedures on who to call, how to report emergencies, what steps to take for various types of emergencies (fire, medical, crime, etc.).
Step 3: Category = Impact Assessment: Does the incident impact any business processes (page 7)?
If yes; CPR to review the Pre-Escalation Action Plan to determine impact to the business and proceeds to next step.
If no; activation is not required.
Review approximate number of impacted employees – CX Centers BCP Dashboard
Step 4: Category = Engage Recovery Teams: CPR engages the recovery teams

Step 5: Category = BFT to Assess Situation: Once the recovery team(s) are convened, the CPR Team and BFT need to review the BFT Discussion Points (12) and determine if the Business Continuity Plan should be activated.
Step 6: Category = BFT Action Plan: Once the recovery team(s) have formed a continuity plan for execution, the CPR team will continue to assist the BFT by executing the BFT Action Plan (page 13).

step_7_category_=_execute_workarounds_im.title: Step 7: Category = Execute Workarounds: Implement the appropriate business continuity strategy in section VI.

content.content: Step 8: Category = Crisis Communication: CPR Team emails the Initial Situation Report (page 13) at the conclusion of the initial BFT call. CPR emails On-going Situation Reports (page 13) every two hours or as appropriate.

Step 9: Category = Return to Normal Operations: When the situation returns to normal, the CPR engages the recovery teams (page 8) to determine closing out the business continuity activation. If the recovery team(s) agrees to end the activation, the CPR will communicate the Return to Normal Operations (page 13).
Step 10: Category = After Action Documentation: Complete the post-activation report and return to onex-bcp-team mailer.
4. When to Activate the BCP
When to Activate the BCP

Using judgement, key stakeholders should determine if the business interruption is severe enough and where it will exceed business-defined recovery time objectives (RTO) to activate the Business Continuity Plan (see next page for in scope processes and the respective RTO).
Other criteria to consider when activating a BCP include:
Geographic Impact: Entire Region / Multiple Regions / Global
Business Units Impacted: Multiple / Corporate-wide
Financial Impact: >$10M
Customer Impact: High
Legal Impact Mandated restricted hours, closure of businesses and schools, or National Guard called to assist local authority
Business Operations Impact: Inability to execute critical elements to maintain acceptable service levels / process failure
Reputational Impact: Regional, National, or International
Employee Impact: Employees requiring hospitalization or employees with critical injuries/death
Absenteeism: >25%

Recovery Teams Procedures
Crisis Communications

this_section_is_designed_for_use_by_the_.title: This section is designed for use by the CPR, BFT members and their delegates, or other key stakeholders to determine if the severity of the incident warrants a Business Continuity Plan activation.

content.content: Roles and Responsibilities
LOB DM/TL reports a BC incident to the CPR team.
The CPR team determines the point person for handling a BC incident, unless this is delegated to an CPR Team (EM).
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.
Pre-Escalation Action Items
After a business continuity incident has occurred, CPR should review the following checklist before contacting the BFT for escalation:
General
How were you made aware of the incident? If an employee reported the incident, what is the person’s name/role within Cisco?
When did the incident occur?
What is the scope of the incident?
Has the Corporate Security Center (CSC) been called?
Validate approximate number of Impacted Personnel using the CXC BCP Dashboard
Operations
What is the impact to Cisco operations? What is the expected duration of the impact on Cisco operations?
Are business processes interrupted or running at a reduced capacity? If so, to what extent are they affected?
Were any customers or clients impacted?
Buildings/Facility
How many buildings/locations were impacted and where?
Is there physical damage and where?
Can employees still access the building(s) that are affected?
Technology
What technology is affected (infrastructure and/or applications)?
Suppliers/Partners
Are there any critical suppliers that are impacted by the incident, and have they activated their BC/DR plans? If so, notify these suppliers.
BFT Discussion Point:
Employee Safety
Assess the event and overall impact on personal safety
Are your direct reports safe?
Alert the Corporate Security Center (CSC) if the event presents a life safety issue
General Response
Is there a need for a physical command center location (i.e., a conference room in case of technology/telecommunication unavailability)
Set a schedule for follow-up meetings and communications
Determine a response and the next steps, including which workarounds should be implemented
Operations
Should any BCP(s) be activated? Which plans?
Are customers impacted? Is there a need to prioritize customers?
Assess the severity and duration of a business function interruption

If employees are relocating to an alternate location, has the desktop support team been contacted to ensure laptops/desktops are available at the new location? Prepare a schedule for staffing of personnel to support all business functions
Identify and obtain any additional resources that are needed to restore critical business functions
Suppliers/Partners
Are Vendors affected? (Determine which function Vendor Managers should join the bridge)
Have any critical suppliers activated their BC and/or DR plans?
Are there alternate supplier/supplier locations that could be used during the incident to maintain continuity of Cisco business activities?
Technology
Is IT troubleshooting the affected technology or has a decision been made to recover the technology at an alternate location? Which technology is affected?
What is the ETA for availability of technology? Which technology?
Contact and Convene the BFT
The DM should contact the CPR team to begin crisis communications via an incident report on CLIP. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:
Start or join a Webex meeting (if available)
Full Webex Teams outage: CPR creates and joins the bridge Epages the SL using the chart below to join the Webex bridge(s)
If Webex is not available, please contact the CPR Team to coordinate an interim solution.
Form the BFT Command Center and Action Plan
Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via Webex and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.
In the case of a pandemic alert (WHO Phase 4+), the Cisco Global Pandemic Coordinator will convene BC teams for pandemic monitoring and response.

Execute the BFT Action Plan
Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
Assign a CPR Team (EM) to manage the business interruption (as necessary)
Assign personnel as needed
Communicate with vendors as required
Act as a decision maker in the allocation of resources during the plan execution period
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Ensure all continuity tasks are appropriately executed
Implementing the appropriate business continuity strategies

Return to Normal Operations
Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
Identify and coordinate requirements to transition back to normal operations
Ensure business function restoration is successful
Inform all required stakeholders of restoration process (business unit, vendors, suppliers, etc.)
Provide return to normal communication to required stakeholders as outlined below
Situation Reports
The Situation report details listed below will be in the following order: Type of Communication, Description of communication, Timeframe to get communication distributed
Initial Situation Report: Within 30 minutes of learning about incident
Describe the event and root cause (if known)
State current impact…how are operations affected (e.g. systems, labs, buildings)
Provide an estimate of the time to restore (if known)
Instruct staff to use an alternative process and provide specific action items (if applicable)
On-going Situation Reports: At the conclusion of each BFT meeting(s)
Updated version of “Initial Situation Report”
Return to Normal Operations: Within 15 minutes of restoration
Brief description of the event
State that the normal operating environment has been restored
Identify and communicate a transition action plan to move from workaround back to normal operating processes.
Instruct staff of specific action items that must be done to ensure that work performed during the outage appears in normal operations systems and logs.
Describe the root cause (if available)

8. Recovery Strategies
Recovery Strategies

The following tables below, outline the workaround and return to normal procedures for each all-hazards approach (technology outage, building/location unavailability, equipment unavailability, and supplier/vendor unavailability).
Technology Outage

Technology Process: BDB-Internal
Strategy/Limitations: No workaround
TAC Escalation Strategy Description: No workaround
Sustainable Timeframe: < 4 Hours
Limitation(s) to Meet SLO: Several automated Jobs that TAC engineers will be impacted also delays auto-processing tools like IRE will cause RMAs longer Processing Times.
Workaround: BDB is a platform used for creating, sharing an executing script that allows automation for predictive and preemptive TAC Support.
No workarounds available.
Backlog Processing/Return to Normal: No Backlog process return to normal; automation task should be re-processed.

Technology Process: Bug Search Tool
Strategy/Limitations: Escalation into the Business Units
Strategy Description: CDETS/Quicker CDETS/DDTS
Sustainable Timeframe: < 12 Hours
Limitation(s) to Meet SLO: Delays in external & internal retrieving bug / defect information
Workaround: BST is used to search for bugs / defects
Teams can use CDETS to view and update bugs. https://cdetsng.cisco.com/webui/#main
Teams can use Quicker CDETS to view bugs. https://scripts.cisco.com/app/quicker_cdets
Teams can use DDTS Display to view bugs. http://wwwin-metrics/ddts.html
Backlog Processing/Return to Normal: No backlog processing.

Technology Process: Business Rules Engine (BRE)
Strategy/Limitations: TAC RMA Creation Service Request Handling TAC Escalation
Strategy Description: Re-route cases
Sustainable Timeframe: < 4 Hours
Limitation(s) to Meet SLO: TAC Engineers will not be able to manage Service Requests via CaseMon in case out an outage or issue.
Workaround: Rules based on which service requests get routed in CSOne.
All cases are assigned to the ‘BCP-GLOBAL’ resource group. Basic Technology/Sub-Technology/Problem Code (T/ST/PC) routing allows cases to be accepted from the ‘BCP-GLOBAL’ queue when the BRE is down, but the rest of CSOne is up
Backlog Processing/Return to Normal: All BCP indicators are removed once the BRE is back up. Regular case routing resumes

Technology Process: CCW – Cisco Commerce Workspace
Strategy/Limitations: Service Request Handling TAC RMA Creation TAC Escalation
Strategy Description: SubID or Connect Dots
Sustainable Timeframe: < 4 Hours
Limitation(s) to Meet SLO: CSAT, delays in service & entitlement due to verification delays
Workaround: Entitlement verification for Support/RMA. Services also include deal, quote, price and order information.
Bypass entitlement for critical / urgent cases
Use SubID to pull up details from Software & Subscriptions (CCS/TFL and Entitlement Escalation Teams) can do this
Connect Dots – https://connectdots.cisco.com/connectdots
Backlog Processing/Return to Normal: No Backlog Processing

Technology Process: Collaboration Learning Intelligence Platform (CLIP)
Strategy/Limitations: Service Request Handling TAC Escalation into the Business Units
Strategy Description: Communicate through alternate means
Sustainable Timeframe: < 4 Hours
Limitation(s) to Meet SLO: Delay in service request resolution, CSAT
Workaround: Escalation Management platform for multiple teams
Engage team leaders, team managers, CAP Managers, known BU contacts, BU aliases via WebEx Teams/Phone
Engage Escalation Leadership for assistance http://www-tac.cisco.com/escalation/index.shtml
For Escalation Logging, retain details in Notepad or other method
Backlog Processing/Return to Normal: Create escalation logs & raise defects / escalations as needed

Technology Process: Connect Dots
Strategy/Limitations: Escalation into the Business Units
Strategy Description: No workaround
Sustainable Timeframe: < 1 day
Limitation(s) to Meet SLO: Possible CSAT
Workaround: Like CCW. Order Management, Warranty, Coverage & Other.
No workaround (tool is non-critical).

SECTION II: Quick Activation and Engagement Guide
This section is designed for use by the CPR, BFT members and their delegates, or other key stakeholders to determine if the severity of the incident warrants a Business Continuity Plan activation.
SECTION V: Recovery Strategies - Business Critical
Recovery strategies & workarounds (Only business critical tools)

Personnel Shortage
Refer to this section if you experience a personnel shortage or if additional requirements are needed for a pandemic.

Recovery Scenarios and Processes

content.content: The objective of the Business Continuity Plan is to minimize impact to critical business processes by coordinating recovery efforts in the event of a disaster or business interruption. Types of disasters and interruptions include both short-term and long-term incidents including, but not limited to, natural disasters, power outages, application outages, terrorism, pandemic, cyberattacks, etc.

A business interruption is defined as any event (anticipated or unanticipated) that disrupts normal business operations. A disaster is defined as a sudden, unplanned catastrophic event compromising an organization’s ability to provide critical business processes or services for an unacceptable period of time.

The plan scope is limited to the business function identified on the cover page only. The plan scope does not include emergency management. The list of business processes covered in this plan can be found on the “Business Process Scope and Recovery Timeframes (RTO)” table.

The BCP applies when a business interruption/disaster directly or indirectly decreases the capacity of our critical business processes which impacts Cisco’s ability to deliver services to our customers. Depending on the impact of the incident, some parts of the plan may not apply.

The BCP is used by key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts of their specific function. The plan is a guide for key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts by facilitating communication, creating an action plan, executing workaround strategies, and returning to normal operations.

section_ii_quick_activation_and_engageme.title: SECTION II: Quick Activation and Engagement Guide

content.content: The following flowchart helps identify if activation of the Business Continuity Plan is required and how to engage the appropriate stakeholders to keep critical business processes operating. See next page for additional details.

Using judgement, key stakeholders should determine if the business interruption is severe enough where it will exceed business-defined recovery time objectives (RTO) to activate the Business Continuity Plan (see next page for in scope processes and the respective RTO).
Other criteria to consider when activating a BCP include:
On-Call Duty Manager (DM)
https://cxlabs-docs.cisco.com/doku.php?id=external:support:support_hours
On-Call CPR Team
CPR- CLIP Instance ( If CLIP is unavailable, go to step 2)
CXC CPR Team On-Call (VPN needed, if unavailable CPR contact information is listed in the BFT)
The BFT coordinates all continuity activities and controls the implementation of the plan.
Cisco Mailer:  cx-labs-bcp@cisco.com
If e-Page is down, utilize the following workarounds
The CFT offers extended response to other functional or physical locations, as needed.
The DM identifies whether a BC incident should be reported to the CPR team.
The CPR team determines the point person for handling a BC incident, unless this is delegated to an Event Manager (EM).
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team  should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.
Contact and Convene the BFT
Once the DM has determined the incident must be escalated i.e the DM should contact the CPR team.
CPR team will assess the impact and pages out the BFT to begin crisis communication. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:
Start or join a WebEx meeting (if available): https://cisco.webex.com/cisco
Full Webex Teams outage:  CPR creates and joins the bridge Epages the SL using the chart below to join the Webex bridge(s)
If Webex is not available, please contact the CPR team to coordinate an interim solution.  CPR on Call.

Form a BFT Command Center and Action Plan

Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via WebEx and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.
In case of a pandemic alert (WHO Phase 4+), the Cisco Global Pandemic Coordinator will convene BC teams for pandemic monitoring and response.

Execute the BFT Action Plan

Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
Assign an Event Manager (EM) to manage the business interruption (as necessary)
Assign personnel as needed
Communicate with vendors as required
Act as a decision maker in the allocation of resources during the plan execution period
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Ensure all continuity tasks are appropriately executed
Implement the appropriate business continuity strategies

Return to Normal Operations

Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
Identify and coordinate requirements to transition back to normal operations
Ensure business function restoration is successful
Inform all required stakeholders of restoration process (business unit, vendors, suppliers, etc.)
Provide return to normal communication to required stakeholders as outlined below
The table below outlines business critical tools and indicates whether alternative solutions are available for each.

Summary of incident: Briefly describe the incident. Incidents can vary and range from personnel, technology, natural disasters, cyber-attacks, etc.

Remediation Steps: Describe each step in as much detail as would be necessary for someone unfamiliar with the system (but technically capable) to follow and complete the remediation. Contact the appropriate stakeholders (recovery teams) and provide crisis communications as necessary. Utilize workaround strategies until service/facility/technology/etc. resumes.

Technologies utilized for the remediation process: List applications, scripts, systems necessary to complete the remediation steps. Standard Cisco applications and several other critical tools such as OmniTool and other apps with their respective recovery strategies listed above.

personnel_skills_required describe_the_n.title: Personnel Skills Required: Describe the number of personnel and specific skills essential for the remediation steps above. Lab Staff: IT knowledge, Engineer, College Grad. Number of staff noted in the personnel shortage section.

content.content: Post remediation monitoring: Describe any logs, dashboards, etc. that should be monitored post-remediation to ensure stability of the recovered system(s). Any offline or manual work should be reconciled as appropriate. Continue to monitor for any further potential issues that may arise.

Post resolution procedures: Describe additional tasks/procedures that should be completed post resolution such as bug reports, configuration changes, change request updates, other potential system failures, etc. Notes may need to be recorded into the appropriate platform. See resumption procedures for applications.

This Business Continuity Plan (BCP) applies to the continuance of the functional areas belonging to the Logistic Support Center (LSC) team in APAC, US, EMEA and JAPAN.
Key areas include site dependencies, critical processes, and applications necessary to support the customer, and resource requirements.
This BCP currently does not cover LSC services for Email, Chat services and Standard Orders support.
Japan is currently out of scope for Premium order dispatch and voice as they are not trained on global dispatch process.
There are approximately 111 Logistics Support Center (LSC) agents globally. For a breakdown of this support, refer to the following table:
The Logistics Support Center (LSC) is organized to offer the following services:
Global Service Relation Call: Handle all calls related to RMA entitlement based on follow-the-sun model (applies for APAC, EMEA and US).
Theatre Voice Calls: Handles all calls related to RMA support.
OMC: Manage all email cases related to RMA support.
Chat service: Manage chat services for all customer/partners who require assistance for PRR tool  (available for all theaters)
Order Dispatch: Manage premium and proactive monitoring of order dispatch via. follow-the-sun model. Standard order is supported and dispatched by local theatres by local cut-off timing.
Refer to http://www.timeanddate.com/time/dst for the exact date period for summer (DST) and Winter (no DST) version.

During the interim period, when not all theaters are aligned with time changes, please use http://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/ to determine the local time of a specific country, or http://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/converter.html to convert time between different countries

Business continuity for LSC is primarily dependent on the network connectivity and supporting infrastructure located at each site.  Network connectivity impacts the ability to deliver services via phone, email and chat and can impact the availability of tools needed to support customers.
In the event of a loss of connectivity, agents would move to a different site (or home) and use VPN to access Cisco Systems and tools.

Availability of certain tools, such as those listed in OM Event Manager is critical to ensure LSC services delivery.  Extended outages that include these tools have a direct impact on LSC Service Levels and on the processes that LSC follows.
Each site has its own geographic or political risks, based on previous experiences.
Costa Rica, India: hurricanes/cyclones
Bulgaria: minor snowstorms, minor earthquakes
Malaysia: Haze, epidemic situation such as SARS
Japan: Earthquakes
By default, the OM Event Manager will assume the lead in executing the business continuity plan.
Assesses the event and overall impact to operations and personal safety.
Assesses the severity and duration of a business function interruption.
Determines the appropriate response.
The following is the list of OM event managers for their respective theatres.
Identify scenario and assess the extent and timeframe of the service(s) impact
Assess that the impacted service(s) is unable to be restored within the acceptable timeframe
Voice > ~1 hour
Premium SORT Orders and Proactive Monitoring> 30 mins

FRED Instructions for TAC DM : http://www-tac.cisco.com/Teams/Duty_Manager/IT_GTRC_Escalation.htm
If issue identified to be related to vendor IT system, ensure vendor IT ticket has been raised for immediate attention.

In the event of major outage, connectivity, or application issues which impact Cisco Contact Centers, Tech Support Escalation team (a.k.a. FRED) will act as a dedicated escalation desk for high impact escalations.  A high impact issue would be something that has a major impact to Cisco Services, Cisco customers or has a finance impacts (i.e.: network, voice, B2B or application outage of an entire contact center or theater).
Please be aware of the new process to contact the Tech Support Escalation Team (aka FRED). Use of hotline numbers has been replaced with an e-page system.
For voice support, after call has been routed to supporting theatre LSC team:
Do note that voice service will only be provided in English.

Only if customer insists on local language support, leverage on Translation Service Support to facilitate a 3-way call (LSC, customer and translator). 
As this is 3-way call, the call duration tends to be longer, therefore, please set expectation with customer upfront. 

More information on how to use this service can be found at Global Interpretation Services Procedure (EDCS-11733123)

Languages supported by Global LSC team (Arabic, Czech, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Mandarin, Polish, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, Thai, Turkish) is available through Translation service.

If LSC do not know language to request, inform Translation Service representative to assist with the request

Scenario 1: Activate Call Routing to another Theatre

OM Event Manager dials in to call routing tool at 89932583, and keys in 4 digits pin code (7723) followed by #.  Dial +1 919 9932583 if using an external phone.

Step 1: Select Outage theatre (1 Concentrix, 2 OnProcess Technology, 3 SCSK)
Step 2: Select Alternate theatre (refer to Supporting theatre. Ensure outage theatre obtains buy-in from supporting theatre OM Event Manager before activation) (1 Concentrix, 2 OnProcess Technology, 3 SCSK)
An email will be sent to cc_telephony_bcp@cisco.com to inform on the call routing activation. Conduct test calls to ensure customer call is properly routed to supporting theatre.
Scenario 2: Activate Call Routing to a Different Phone Number
– Take the script that is currently in place and point to the new number
– If unable to re-route script currently in place, CCAT engineer will need to build a new script to be able to route to a different phone number
– Take the script that is currently in place and point to the new number
OM Event Manager will setup a call bridge with all appropriate parties (following normal WebEx meeting procedures) and prepare to meet with OM BCP team with available info about:
Cause of the business interruption.
Summary of any personal injuries, damage to buildings, infrastructure and equipment.
What business functions have been affected and to what extent.
Recommended workarounds, actions taken, next steps.
Recommendation to invoke Theatre and/or Global BCP process.
OM Duty Manager/ Event Manager sends Duty Manager Notification to inform all relevant stakeholders of BCP event progress and to list who the POC is for engagement in the DM notification.
Impacted theatre OM Event Manager/ Duty Manager to keep in contact with supporting theatre Event Manager every hour to review situation progress.
Scenario 3: De-activate Call Routing (if scenario 1 was activated)
OM Event Manager dial in to call routing tool at 89932583, and key in 4-digit pin code (7723) followed by#.
Dial +1 919 9932583 If using external phone.
Step 1 : OM Event Manager dial in to call routing tool at 89932583, and key in 4-digit pin code (7723) followed by #. Dial +1 919 9932583 If using external phone.
Step 2 : Select option 5 (turn off call routing)
Step 3 : An email will be sent to cc_telephony_bcp@cisco.com to inform call routing de-activation. Conduct test calls to ensure call routing is switched off.
Step 4 : Once the situation is resolved, OM Event Manager informs OM DM to send final restoration of service communication and resume normal business state.
Note: In the event call routing is activated, impacted theatre Event Manager to login to utility tool to turn off disaster recovery routing and conduct test calls.

tableOfContents.title: SECTION I: Introduction to the Business Continuity Plan (BCP)
SECTION II: Quick Activation and Engagement Guide
This section is designed for use by the CPR, BFT members and their delegates, or other key stakeholders to determine if the severity of the incident warrants a Business Continuity Plan activation.
SECTION V: Recovery Strategies – Business Critical

Personnel Shortage
Refer to this section if you experience a personnel shortage or if additional requirements are needed for a pandemic.

Recovery Scenarios and Processes

Fill out the section below for all potential scenarios (4 examples below) for which your Business Process can be impacted. Separate into different sections for scenarios where remediation steps are not the same.

content.content: The objective of the Business Continuity Plan is to minimize impact to critical business processes by coordinating recovery efforts in the event of a disaster or business interruption. Types of disasters and interruptions include both short-term and long-term incidents including, but not limited to, natural disasters, power outages, application outages, terrorism, pandemic, cyberattacks, etc.

A business interruption is defined as any event (anticipated or unanticipated) that disrupts normal business operations. A disaster is defined as a sudden, unplanned catastrophic event compromising an organization’s ability to provide critical business processes or services for an unacceptable period of time.

The plan scope is limited to the business function identified on the cover page only. The plan scope does not include emergency management. The list of business processes covered in this plan can be found on the “Business Process Scope and Recovery Timeframes (RTO)” table.

The BCP applies when a business interruption/disaster directly or indirectly decreases the capacity of our critical business processes which impacts Cisco’s ability to deliver services to our customers. Depending on the impact of the incident, some parts of the plan may not apply.

The BCP is used by key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts of their specific function. The plan is a guide for key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts by facilitating communication, creating an action plan, executing workaround strategies, and returning to normal operations.

section_ii_quick_activation_and_engageme.title: SECTION II: Quick Activation and Engagement Guide

content.content: The following flowchart helps identify if activation of the Business Continuity Plan is required and how to engage the appropriate stakeholders to keep critical business processes operating. See next page for additional details.

Using judgement, key stakeholders should determine if the business interruption is severe enough where it will exceed business-defined recovery time objectives (RTO) to activate the Business Continuity Plan (see next page for in scope processes and the respective RTO).
Other criteria to consider when activating a BCP include:
On-Call CPR Team
CPR Team Incident Open and Epage (CLIP link; if NaaS or CLIP unavailable, go to step 2)
CXC CPR Team On-Call (VPN needed, if unavailable CPR contact information is listed with the BFT)

The BFT coordinates all continuity activities and controls the implementation of the plan.
ePage: cxc-ps-globalbft
The CFT offers extended response to other functional or physical locations, as needed.
The CPR team determines the point person for handling a BC incident, unless this is delegated to an Event Manager (EM).
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.
Contact and Convene the BFT
CPR team will assess the impact and pages out the BFT to begin crisis communication. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:
Start or join a WebEx meeting (if available): https://cisco.webex.com/cisco
Full Webex Teams outage:  CPR creates and joins the bridge Epages the SL using the chart below to join the Webex bridge(s)
If Webex is not available, please contact the CPR team to coordinate an interim solution.
The following additional resource(s) can be used to convene the BFT:
ePage: cxc-ps-globalbft

Form a BFT Command Center and Action Plan

Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via WebEx and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.
In case of a pandemic alert (WHO Phase 4+), the Cisco Global Pandemic Coordinator will convene BC teams for pandemic monitoring and response.

Execute the BFT Action Plan

Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
Assign an Event Manager (EM) to manage the business interruption (as necessary)
Assign personnel as needed
Communicate with vendors as required
Act as a decision maker in the allocation of resources during the plan execution period
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Ensure all continuity tasks are appropriately executed
Implement the appropriate business continuity strategies

Return to Normal Operations

Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
Identify and coordinate requirements to transition back to normal operations
Ensure business function restoration is successful
Inform all required stakeholders of restoration process (business unit, vendors, suppliers, etc.)
Provide return to normal communication to required stakeholders as outlined below
In the event of a significant process disruption or vendor outage, the following vendors should be contacted, as they all provide the same staffing support.

The following tables below outlines the workaround and return to normal procedures for each all-hazards approach (technology outage, building/location unavailability, equipment unavailability, and supplier/vendor unavailability).

recent business impact analysis.

Using judgement, key stakeholders should determine if the business interruption is severe enough where it will exceed business-defined recovery time objectives (RTO) to activate the Business Continuity Plan (see next page for in scope processes and the respective RTO).
Other criteria to consider when activating a BCP include:
On-Call Duty Manager (DM)
https://schedule.cisco.com/
On-Call CPR Team
CPR- CLIP Instance ( If CLIP is unavailable, go to step 2)
CXC CPR Team On-Call (VPN needed, if unavailable CPR contact information is listed in the BFT)
The BFT coordinates all continuity activities and controls the implementation of the plan.
Cisco Mailer: sourcedsupport-us-bft@cisco.com, sourcedsupport-emear-crisis@cisco.com, sourcedsupport-apjc-bft@cisco.com, ww-dm@cisco.com
If e-Page is down, utilize the following workarounds
The CFT offers extended response to other functional or physical locations, as needed.
The DM identifies whether a BC incident should be reported to the CPR team.
The CPR team determines the point person for handling a BC incident, unless this is delegated to an Event Manager (EM).
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team  should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.

Contact and Convene the BFT

Once the DM has determined the incident must be escalated i.e the DM should contact the CPR team.
CPR team will assess the impact and pages out the BFT to begin crisis communication. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:
Start or join a WebEx meeting (if available): https://cisco.webex.com/cisco
Full Webex Teams outage:  CPR creates and joins the bridge Epages the SL using the chart below to join the Webex bridge(s)
If Webex is not available, please contact the CPR team to coordinate an interim solution.CPR On- Call

Form a BFT Command Center and Action Plan

Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via WebEx and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.
In case of a pandemic alert (WHO Phase 4+), the Cisco Global Pandemic Coordinator will convene BC teams for pandemic monitoring and response.

Execute the BFT Action Plan

Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
Assign an Event Manager (EM) to manage the business interruption (as necessary)
Assign personnel as needed
Communicate with vendors as required
Act as a decision maker in the allocation of resources during the plan execution period
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Ensure all continuity tasks are appropriately executed
Implement the appropriate business continuity strategies

Return to Normal Operations

Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
Identify and coordinate requirements to transition back to normal operations
Ensure business function restoration is successful
Inform all required stakeholders of restoration process (business unit, vendors, suppliers, etc.)
Provide return to normal communication to required stakeholders as outlined below

recovery_scenarios_and_processes\n\nfill.title:
Recovery Scenarios and Processes

Fill out the section below for all potential scenarios (4 examples below) for which your Business Process can be impacted. Separate into different sections for scenarios where remediation steps are not the same.

content.content: Scenario Types:
Natural Disaster (Earthquake, Tornado, Flooding, anything applicable to your geographical location, etc.)
Technological (Network outage, DNS outage, communications outage, critical application outage etc.)
Human/Community Impact (Pandemic, War, etc.)
Cyber Attack (Critical application hacked for your business process and data stolen)
Summary of incident: Briefly describe the incident. Incidents can vary and range from personnel, technology, natural disasters, cyber-attacks, etc.

Remediation Steps: Describe each step in as much detail as would be necessary for someone unfamiliar with the system (but technically capable) to follow and complete the remediation. Contact the appropriate stakeholders (recovery teams) and provide crisis communications as necessary. Utilize workaround strategies until service/facility/technology/etc. resumes.

Technologies utilized for the remediation process: List applications, scripts, systems necessary to complete the remediation steps. Standard Cisco applications and Support Case Manager, CSOne, etc. are used frequently for the business processes. Recovery strategies listed above.

Personnel Skills Required: Describe the number of personnel and specificskills essential for the remediation steps above. Thousands of staff performing the critical business processes in over 10+ locations with general skillsets listed under personnel requirements.

Post remediation monitoring: Describe any logs, dashboards, etc. that should be monitored post-remediation to ensure stability of the recovered system(s). All backlog processing required should be completed.

Post resolution procedures: Describe additional tasks/procedures that should be completed post resolution such as bug reports, configuration changes, change request updates, other potential system failures, etc. N/A

BCP Routing

BCP routing preparation
• Depending on the time of day of the voice outage, TS DM need to confirm with the Onsite vendor contact if agents at the selected vendor offsite location are ready to take overflow calls. The alternate Vendor will receive calls at the numbers/scripts listed as below:

To turn on BCP routing, please skilled your agents on the BCP skillgroups (CIN_BCP_EN_S1S2, CIN_BCP_EN_SS3S4,, CIN_BCP_CFL_OTH) then BCP routing can be activated per below steps:
• Dial BCP Utility at 89932505 (PIN 3693, external Dial +1 919 993 2505) 
• Select Option 7 (BCP Enterprise Skillgroups)
• Calls will then be routed to the agents available in the above BCP skillgroups
To turn BCP routing OFF, dial the utility and select opt 4
BCP utility option list
After Select Outage Theaters,  select Alternate theater of choice (APAC/EMEA/US) or select option 4 if NO alternate theater is available to play BCP message for TFL and SBSC as below:

tableOfContents.title: SECTION I: Introduction to the Business Continuity Plan (BCP)
SECTION II: Quick Activation and Engagement Guide
This section is designed for use by the CPR, BFT members and their delegates, or other key stakeholders to determine if the severity of the incident warrants a Business Continuity Plan activation.
SECTION III: Business Process Scope and Recovery Timeframes (RTO)
TAC Business Critical Tools and Processes

Personnel Shortage
Refer to this section if you experience a personnel shortage or if additional requirements are needed for a pandemic.

Recovery Scenarios and Processes

Fill out the section below for all potential scenarios (4 examples below) for which your Business Process can be impacted. Separate into different sections for scenarios where remediation steps are not the same.

content.content: The objective of the Business Continuity Plan is to minimize impact to critical business processes by coordinating recovery efforts in the event of a disaster or business interruption. Types of disasters and interruptions include both short-term and long-term incidents including, but not limited to, natural disasters, power outages, application outages, terrorism, pandemic, cyberattacks, etc.

A business interruption is defined as any event (anticipated or unanticipated) that disrupts normal business operations. A disaster is defined as a sudden, unplanned catastrophic event compromising an organization’s ability to provide critical business processes or services for an unacceptable period of time.

The plan scope is limited to the business function identified on the cover page only. The plan scope does not include emergency management. The list of business processes covered in this plan can be found on the “Business Process Scope and Recovery Timeframes (RTO)” table.

The BCP applies when a business interruption/disaster directly or indirectly decreases the capacity of our critical business processes which impacts Cisco’s ability to deliver services to our customers. Depending on the impact of the incident, some parts of the plan may not apply.

The BCP is used by key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts of their specific function. The plan is a guide for key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts by facilitating communication, creating an action plan, executing workaround strategies, and returning to normal operations.
There are a few terms mentioned in the document that are worth highlighting and defined as follows:
BFT: Business Function Team (Primary Contacts to be Alerted)
DM:  On-call Duty Manager
RTO: Recovery Time Objective
CXC CPR: CXC Crisis Preparedness and Response Team

section_ii_quick_activation_and_engageme.title: SECTION II: Quick Activation and Engagement Guide

content.content: The following flowchart helps identify if activation of the Business Continuity Plan is required and how to engage the appropriate stakeholders to keep critical business processes operating. See next page for additional details.

Using judgement, key stakeholders should determine if the business interruption is severe enough where it will exceed business-defined recovery time objectives (RTO) to activate the Business Continuity Plan (see next page for in scope processes and the respective RTO).
Other criteria to consider when activating a BCP include:
On-Call Duty Manager (DM)
On-Call Duty Manager Schedule (VPN needed)
On-Call CPR Team
CPR Team Incident Open and Epage (If NaaS E-Page or CLIP unavailable, go to step 2)
CXC CPR Team On-Call (VPN needed, if unavailable CPR contact information is listed with the BFT)
The BFT coordinates all continuity activities and controls the implementation of the plan.
Cisco e-page: tac-bft (Link to NaaS [E-Page])
If ePage is down (or recipient is not using NaaS), utilize the following workarounds
The CFT offers extended response to other functional or physical locations, as needed.
The LOB DM reports a BC incident to the CPR team.
The CPR team determines the point person for handling a BC incident, unless this is delegated to an CPR Team (EM).
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.

Contact and Convene the BFT

The DM should contact the CPR team to begin crisis communications via an incident report. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:
Start or join a Webex meeting (if available): https://cisco.webex.com/cisco
Full Webex Teams outage:  CPR creates and joins the bridge Epages the SL using the chart below to join the Webex bridge(s)
If Webex is not available, please contact the CPR Team to coordinate an interim solution.
Form a BFT Command Center and Action Plan
Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via Webex and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.
In case of a pandemic alert (WHO Phase 4+), the Cisco Global Pandemic Coordinator will convene BC teams for pandemic monitoring and response.

Execute the BFT Action Plan

Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
Assign an CPR Team (EM) to manage the business interruption (as necessary)
Assign personnel as needed
Communicate with vendors as required
Act as a decision maker in the allocation of resources during the plan execution period
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Ensure all continuity tasks are appropriately executed
Implement the appropriate business continuity strategies

Return to Normal Operations

Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
Identify and coordinate requirements to transition back to normal operations
Ensure business function restoration is successful
Inform all required stakeholders of restoration process (business unit, vendors, suppliers, etc.)
Provide return to normal communication to required stakeholders as outlined below

recovery_scenarios_and_processes\n\nfill.title:
Recovery Scenarios and Processes

Fill out the section below for all potential scenarios (4 examples below) for which your Business Process can be impacted. Separate into different sections for scenarios where remediation steps are not the same.

content.content: Scenario Types:
Natural Disaster (Earthquake, Tornado, Flooding, anything applicable to your geographical location, etc.)
Technological (Network outage, DNS outage, communications outage, critical application outage etc.)
Human/Community Impact (Pandemic, War, etc.)
Cyber Attack (Critical application hacked for your business process and data stolen)
Summary of incident: Briefly describe the incident. Incidents can vary and range from personnel, technology, natural disasters, cyber-attacks, etc.

Remediation Steps: Describe each step in as much detail as would be necessary for someone unfamiliar with the system (but technically capable) to follow and complete the remediation. Contact the appropriate stakeholders (recovery teams) and provide crisis communications as necessary. Utilize workaround strategies until service/facility/technology/etc. resumes.

Technologies utilized for the remediation process: List applications, scripts, systems necessary to complete the remediation steps. Standard Cisco applications and several other critical tools such as CSOne and other apps with their respective recovery strategies listed above.

Personnel Skills Required: Describe the number of personnel and specific skills essential for the remediation steps above. Customer Service, Cisco Equipment Experience, diploma or technical background.

Post remediation monitoring: Describe any logs, dashboards, etc. that should be monitored post-remediation to ensure stability of the recovered system(s). Any offline or manual work should be reconciled as appropriate. Continue to monitor for any further potential issues that may arise.

Post resolution procedures: Describe additional tasks/procedures that should be completed post resolution such as bug reports, configuration changes, change request updates, other potential system failures, etc. Notes may need to be recorded into the appropriate platform. See resumption procedures for applications.
